text: Stayed for 4 nights in this secluded resort. Initial impressions positive. Villas can be a long way from the hotel buildings. You can be reliant on the electric buggies but if the internal phone, to summonse the buggy, does not work like ours  you have to walk in the rain and dark even with the supplied torch. A major problem is the poor food quality. Restaurant service very slow, plates cold, food cold or tepid even when reheated. All meat dishes very tough and some unedible. It may be coincidence but 75% of our group went down with stomach problems. The villa was nice but we had two water leaks. These were 'solved' by Staff puting towels down. Basin water was only ever tepid including the 'cold' water tap. In view of the poor food quality would not stay here again.

1. I am delighted that you liked the structure of the reception pavilion, the many exotic birds on site including the hundreds of wandering peacocks and peahens, the enormous main swimming pool with stunning views of the Lion Rock and the staffing in the main restaurant.  As you have suggested, I will indeed take a deep and long look at the negative concerns you have raised and will take corrective action should I find the need to do so.  To further clarify;

2. As the name signifies, there are many water bodies on site in the form of ponds, lakes and water ways. There are many marine eco systems thriving in these water bodies not to mention hundreds of fish who eat the larvae of the mosquitoes and who have a zero chance of breeding in our water bodies. 

3. There are 4 resident mugger crocodiles in the main lake at the entrance of the hotel and we have built custom made islands for them to bask in the sun and regulate their body temperatures. The many water bodies are thriving with hundreds of local lake fish however fishing by humans is banned within the property as these fish are part of a food chain for the many species of birds and mugger crocs. 4. The hotel is set in 38 acres of landscaped gardens and waterways. As was explained to you by your butler during the hotel and villa orientation, we have electric golf buggies which are on call at any given time to drive you from one location to another. The reason for this being to safeguard the comfort and privacy of all our resident guests which included yourselves when you were staying with us. Thank you for bringing your concerns to our attention via this review but what would have been a win-win situation for yourselves and us is if you had raised these concerns either with me or any other Manager during your stay.

text:
Despite a picture postcard view of Sri Lanka’s most famous rock fortress, this pricey hotel on the outskirts of Sirigiya, is more stage set than hotel. It features 30 comfortably furnished one bedroom villas -many with private plunge pools -that encircle a manmade “water garden”.  But the “water garden” itself is a string of stagnant water holes that serve as magnets for mosquitoes and are filled with crocodiles (!) – or so we were cautioned by staff  - which made walking around the poorly lit property especially precarious at night. 

Arrival at the hotel, past the locked gate and exquisitely designed reception pavillion,is spectacular. But the reception itself is chilly and devoid of charm. Such a shame. The hotel’s jungle like setting attracts many exotic birds; including enormous peacocks we enjoyed watching take flight. The main swimming pool is enormous and beautiful; as is the dining room, which is staffed with well-meaning and attentive waiters. But the rest of hotel is in serious need of better trained -  and happier - staff. For example, the “butler” we were assigned refused to help us obtain mineral water. He volunteered to take us back and forth to the dining room in the hotel’s golf cart but kept us waiting over a half hour each time. Housekeeping was sloppy. Among the many hotels we stayed in wonderful Sri Lanka, Water Garden Sirigiya was the only one in which we sensed management did not treat or train its household staff well.
title: Spectacular View But Devoid of Charm

Indeed, the property is gorgeous! Unfortunately, the staff — while kind — was not sufficiently well trained for a resort of this caliber. Service was slow at the front desk, in the bar, and in the restaurant. The food at the restaurant was mediocre at best. We really wanted to give this hotel five stars. The staff was so nice to us and really tried hard to ensure we had a good time. Many of our concerns with the hotel are outside of the staff's control. We understand that this is considered a boutique hotel and they were limited with their resources, however, we hope that in the future, the hotel can improve with several different things. 

PROS: 

(1) Beautiful location. The hotel is located on a peninsula overlooking a beautiful ocean. There are two beaches to walk on - which is perfect during sunset. 
(2) Excellent service. The hotel staff treated us like kings. They also wanted to ensure we were having a good time. They provided us with a romantic dinner by the pool, served us a complimentary breakfast in our suite, and gave us a complimentary 100 minute massage. We enjoyed all of these things. 

CONS: 
(1) Outdated. This hotel was built over 20 years ago. Apparently it is going to have some major renovations in a few months, so it might be best to wait to come to this hotel until after the renovations (or get a good deal to come). My wife noted that the furniture and decorations were rather depressing and bland. The furnishing and materials did not appear to have been updated over the years and the cushions and pillows were discolored from fading and were stained. The material of these items were also itchy and non-inviting. The chairs appeared cheaply covered by towels and seemed run-down. The bedspread and other linens would have been more appropriate for a lower-cost stay such as an AirBNB. Possibly due to the outdated containers but the toiletries, such as shampoo and conditioner did not appear updated. We also had concerns about the cleanliness of the place as twice the linens had dark hairs on them and one towel was dirty when opened up. The bedroom doors had cracks to the outside (see picture). Consequently, we had bugs and insects inside our rooms and the beds do not have mosquito nets. All of the other hotels we stayed at (Water Garden Sigiriya, Wild Coast Tented Lodge, Ceylon Tea Trails and Kings Pavilion) had mosquito nets over the bed. It is also important to note that of all the locations we stayed at, this location had the most mosquitos. 
(2) Poor Value. We paid a lot for this hotel - more than Water Garden Sigiriya and Kings Pavilion, but felt it was too expensive for what was offered / the luxury provided. We felt our money went a lot farther at Water Garden Sigiriya and Kings Pavilion. We completely understand however, that our payments help pay for its location and the staff. 
(3) Lack of activities. The resort offers numerous activities that they will help schedule and always appeared eager to help in whatever way possible. The lack of on-site activities was still a problem in our opinion because it is less appealing to schedule a driver and activity.
(4) Poor communication: We found that for the most part, the staff had a difficult time speaking English. This should be expected since we are in a non-English speaking country. But of all the hotels we stayed it, we found this place the most difficult to communicate with the staff. For example, we called for room service and the attendant and I could not communicate. So he had to send someone else to our room so we can point to what we wanted on the menu. On another occasion, we asked 3 different staff members on what we should tip our driver to water sports activities. All 3 staff (including a manager) refused to answer. We eventually were told what we should tip as we were entering the tuk tuk. This was an important question for us because we did not want to tip too much, but we also did not want to disrespect the driver by not tipping enough. When we asked the hotel for advice, we expected them to easily give us an answer. 
(5) Food. The food was very bland. Some of the dishes were great (the soups were great), but it did not even come close to the other hotels that we stayed at. Many of the entrees were overcooked. We did however, love their homemade ice cream. 

Final Note: We loved Sri Lanka and hope the management makes several changes with the new renovation coming. Next time we are back in Sri Lanka, we are definitely willing to give this hotel another chance. Also, this place is great if you just want a relaxing time with good views and a very kind staff.

Now for the cons. There is a certain shoddiness to the place that should not be present in a 5 star resort. Furniture in our room was worn around the edges, tiles in the bathroom were stained, the silver faucet in the bathroom was tarnished and green, there was mold around our door entrance and one the private pool tiles came off. Even the doors in our room didn’t quite close correctly (seems the wood had warped on the edges so that gaps emerged).

Also, don’t expect any local recommendations from staff aside from pre-prepared tour packages. They couldn’t offer any recommendations within Bentota except for the only other 5 star resort. (By the way, there are plenty of local places to check out).
 
The spa is average.. staff there are very friendly but technique is not particularly outstanding. It is in a nice outdoor environment though.
 
Reading through other reviews, I’ve seen that management’s standard response to poor reviews was that this hotel should not be compared to a 5 star resort as it is an “authentic Sri Lankan experience”.  I completely disagree with this, because if I’m paying inflated prices that equal other 5 star resorts globally (regardless of whether Saman Villas’ rates are cheaper during low season), I still expect 5 star quality.
 
Sadly out of all hotels in Sri Lanka, this was the biggest disappointment.

Saman Villas is a lovely tranquil spot in Bentota, about 60Km south of Columbo. The rooms were beautiful with out own pool, the restaurant was very nice and although you could not call it fine dining, there was a good choice with an interesting asian flavour as one might expect. There were very few people staying there (off peak) and we usually had the main pool more or less to ourselves. 
There were two downsides, firstly the journey to and from Columbo, (we had underestimated the terrible roads) and secondly the outcome of us losing a room key. This led to a $200 fee which we considered exorbitant even if they did have to replace a lock. There was no warning in advance and this hotel was certainly not cheap in the first place. Even the idea that they would charge in dollars rather than local currency suggested a penalty rather than a replacement cost. We asked to speak to the manager who was spoken to by staff on the phone but who refused to speak to us. The staff told us they would lose their jobs if we wouldn't pay. I don't know whether this was true or not but they had been very nice to us so we paid so as not to find out!. Unfortunately, this left a sour taste in the mouth after an otherwise enjoyable few days.
title: don't lose your key

ownerResponse/text:
We thank the reviewer for their recent stay at Saman Villas and commending the hotels tranquil setting, bathroom and attend to detail.

Our reply is intended to our prospective guests lest they get the wrong impression that our room rates, food and beverage prices are excessive and not competitive. 
All of us like to buy everything cheap but only a very few guests have commented that our prices are too high. A brief explanation of our pricing policy may help to clarify these concerns.
 
ROOM RATES ARE TOO HIGH
1. Prices are determined according to demand. From last week of December to second week of March the demand is very high due to holiday season (X mas, New Year and Chinese New Year) and more importantly European and Russian Winter. Naturally during such periods prices are high. The same room that the reviewer paid USD 603 ++ is available at USD 411 ++ for the same number of nights, any time from 01st April to 31st October. We offer prices and special offers to suit many budgets. Why come at the most expensive period and complain, when in fact you can have the same room very much cheaper for a continuous period of 7 months. 

2. Price differences for rooms with pools and without pools for the period of the review are given below. 

BED & BREAKFAST RATES
Deluxe Suite without Pool                                        USD  529++
Deluxe Suite with Pool          				         USD  603++
Grand Deluxe Suite with Pool (much more privacy) USD  673++
Saman Villa Suite with Pool(absolute privacy)         USD  733++

Deluxe Suite with Pool has two major advantages; a 22 foot lap pool and a secluded garden for private use. The difference between Deluxe Suite without Pool and with pool is only USD 74++. We offer rooms with greater privacy at a higher supplement for those who are excessively concerned about privacy.  

FOOD PRICES ARE HIGH
Please compare quality, variety, range, choices  and prices of our food with any boutique hotel of similar size anywhere in the world and you will find our food is reasonably priced. We offer a total of 84 dishes comprising soups, starters, menus, snacks and desserts and a daily 4 course set menu with 9 choices which vary daily in a two week cycle. To provide this huge menu whilst conforming to HACCP food safety standards, we carry a large range of raw materials and mise en place. In addition, we employ an experienced and qualified foreign executive chef (currently on leave) and a large team of highly experienced cooks. Naturally our costs are high. All this effort is primarily to delight our customers with the best and at reasonable prices. Almost all our guests love our food. 

BEVERAGE PRICES ARE HIGH
In Sri Lanka foreign liquor is considered non-essential and the ultimate luxury. In addition, foreign liquor is an important revenue generator for the government. Hence duty is extremely high compared to the Western World and most other countries. However, our prices are not higher than any boutique hotel of similar standard anywhere in the world.

Thank you

text:
As has been said by other reviewers this is a beautifully laid out resort, great attention to detail in the rooms, gorgeous bathrooms and a tranquil setting. However the reason for only giving 3 stars is value for money. At £500 per night B and B I had expected villa with private pool to be just that - private. I did not expect the villas to be 2 storey with others sitting on their verandas overlooking our pool area (see photo taken in the pool on the farthest side from the villa). Whilst I realise the couple upstairs had better things to do than sit and look at us all day, the fact that they were there, and so close was very disconcerting. Unfortunately said upstairs guests were both unwell with hacking coughs which disturbed us constantly. We tried to change rooms but were told that all the rooms with pools were occupied. We appreciate that it is not the hotel's fault that our upstairs neighbours were ill but maybe an emollient word from one of the managers (we were told the manager would be informed of our discontent) would have made for good customer relations. Even a complimentary bottle of wine might have made us feel that they cared that we were unhappy. We were offered a change of room on our penultimate night but the upstairs people were leaving that day anyway. 
Restaurant food was good but quite prices. Ditto drinks. 
In short, lovely place mostly but very overpriced for what you get. Have stayed in far better for much less.
title: Private pool but no privacy

We thank the reviewer for their recent stay at Saman Villas. Thank you for commending on the location, tranquil atmosphere, open-air bathroom, Garden, food and staff.

Our rates vary throughout the year. In fact there are 4 different rate periods depending on many factors such as holiday season, weather, festivities, demand, etc. The cheapest is from 16th March to 31st October  and most expensive from 24th  December to 9th January . The latter is the only period we could not meet the demand and hence the high rate is justifiable. Our rate structure is flexible to the extent that a traveler can have a very cheap holiday with special offers. 

The website clearly explains the type of luxury the hotel offers “A modern-day interpretation of Sri Lankan culture and  style. The complete room layout including the furniture style and setting are clearly mentioned along with the room photos, so that the clients are well aware of what exactly to expect prior to making their booking. Apart  from the furniture in the room as mentioned by the reviewer extra furniture such as a sofa, a planters chair and a wooden table with 2 chairs are placed in the terrace/balcony  in every room. 

Many of our guests praise the air-conditioning we have in the suites and we were rather surprised with the reviewers comments. We provide Daikin invertor type air-conditioning units. The two whisper quite indoor units are placed in each suite to have an improve air distribution. The units do not make any howling sound unlike other air conditioners. Both air-conditioning units can be operated at a very low speed with a comfortable temperature rather than managing with one unit at a higher speed and lower temperature. We personally inspected the suite occupied by the reviewer and  found  no issues with the air conditioner.

We have over 50 dishes in our menu which covers preferences of majority of guests. Had the reviewer informed us that they were not happy with the choices and required a tailor made dish, our Chefs would have gladly prepared any dish to the reviewer’s preference.  We always go off our menu to delight our guests and cater to their meal preferences.

Thank you.

I am sorry that I have given this place 3 stars and not 5 but I was beyond frustrated with their hidden charging policy. Also I found they could have made much more effort with the beach area. The beds were few and far between and they were never neat. To get to the beach you pass a small area of land that they could do so much with. Instead it was bland  and boring and not at all inspiring.  On the positive side, their  suites were FANTASTIC. We had 2 bedrooms and loved the layout. The suite was clean and the views amazing. I could not fault the room at all. This was 5 stars. 
Where this hotel needs to make changes is with their price advertising when you are there. They were the ONLY hotel and bar that we visited in Sir Lanka, that did not include government tax when laying out their prices on their menus. So you assumed you were paying the price stated. In fact they then added 34% on top! This included 24% for tax and then 10% for service. Please in future, let your guests know this by stating this clearly on the menus and not in small print either. Let guests know that the prices are plus 34%. The wine is expensive here especially when they add on that 34%, so beware. 
Also in the rooms there was no plates, knives and forks etc. We were told this is extra! Seems a silly policy when you provide a kitchen. We did not cook, so did not bother us particularly. Also be aware that the items provided in the room such as snacks and drinks also have 34% added on to the advertised pricing. 
So long as you are aware of the lack of transparency with pricing, I would highly recommend their suites.  They themselves, were well worth the price paid.
title: 5 star suites but poor transparency with their pricing once you are at the resort.

text:
My fiancé & I are seasoned luxury travellers. We spent 10 days travelling around in Sri Lanka, and EKHO Ella was supposed to be the highlight of our trip. I booked the honeymoon suite and expected great things due to the positive reviews on Booking.com. 

Sadly the room was tired (furniture and soft furnishings were old and worn out), dirty (the walls need a lick of paint, and the soft furnishings were stained and need replacing). The room was dark, and the only natural light came from the jacuzzi area which is a shame. We could only enjoy the view from the garden, but not from our room. There is no pool which is crazy for the price the charge (£220 per night).

The jacuzzi in our room felt dirty and uninviting. The biggest problem was that whenever there was a power cut in the area, the jacuzzi automatically reset itself and turned on. During our stay there were 4 power cuts at night, which meant that between 2am - 4am the jacuzzi turned on and started spraying water literally everywhere around the room. Needless to say that we didn't get much sleep at night as power cuts are quite common in Sri Lanka. The room next to ours also had a jacuzzi. As jacuzzis are loud creatures, the neighbouring rooms can definitely hear them. 

There was a speaker in the hallway just outside of our room, so we could hear the music from our bed (eg. acoustic version on Linking Park was playing close to 10pm...), which is not necessarily what we wanted during your romantic stay. 

Dinner in the restaurant was good, but breakfast was rather sad. It is such a shame, because the staff are literally the nicest people we have ever met in our entire lives, and couldn't have been more helpful and more professional. 

We were supposed to stay in the hotel for 2 nights, but checked out after our first night. We relocated to 5* hotel in Ella which was honestly breathtaking (we had our own little chalet with a view over the tea plantation, 5* food and 5* service, plus pool and spa) for £150 per night.

So my advice is not to be fooled by the clever photos and rave reviews on booking.com. The hotel has potential, but you're better off staying somewhere else in Ella for less money and a better overall experience.
title: Sadly this hotel doesn't deliver on its promise...

The beds were super comfy and big, and I was lucky to be given a free upgrade as they only had a few other guests. And it is an excellent place to meet other solo travellers, almost everyone there when I was there was travelling solo like me, and I ended up travelling with a few of them afterwards. text:
I spent two weeks at the Surfer in Weligama and have mixed feelings.

Accommodation:
The rooms are spacious, if a little bare. Shower is ok, low pressure, not always hot or even warm water, but that’s ok in this part of the world. My room did not have AC, just a fan - I'm not sure whether there are rooms with AC but if so, better to take one of those. While I was there, they only cleaned the room every 5 days which is not enough, plus I had only a linen sheet as a blanket, but no actual linen on the mattress itself. This kind of makes you question the hygiene. To be fair though, I never complained about this and just used my travel sleeping bag. 
The camp has a pool which is cleaned daily. There’s a few loungers/sunbeds. There’s a construction site next door at the moment, they’re usually working from early in the morning, but this can happen everywhere. 
Wifi hardly ever works properly and often not at all, also not unusual in this neck of the woods, but if you’re reliant on a working internet connection, you may want to buy a local SIM card or have some data package from home (granted, 3/4G often also doesn’t work)

Food & restaurant
The restaurant is on the third floor and has several couches, hammocks and a few swinging chairs - plus a nice view of the ocean. It makes for a great place to hang, chill, eat, have a beer, whatever you prefer.
The food is fine as is the selection. While the service is friendly, the speed and organization at meal times are sometimes a challenge. Especially during breakfast time, people often had to wait 1 hour+ for their food, which led to a few grumpy reactions by some - understandably. It’s not really anyone’s fault, probably, but maybe with some preparation, this could be organized in a much easier way (e.g. there are several breakfast options, maybe just make it a buffet or at least prepare some of it, e.g. the fruit platters and toast, upfront). Every now and then the orders were not delivered at all. Around dinner time, this seems to have been less of a problem and staff were usually also able to accommodate special dietary needs or wishes if you explained them carefully.
There are also yoga lessons on the rooftop, with a very flexible schedule, often at sunset - very nice.

Community feel:
You will meet people from all over the world here, there are almost daily special events at the rooftop bar/restaurant (e.g. BBQ, movie nights, etc.). I’ve seen quieter camps before, this one is definitely a bit more on the partying side, which isn’t bad, but you should be aware of it. If you're looking for a quiet romantic getaway, this hotel isn't for you.

Surfing lessons:
There is a beach break right in front of the hotel. The beach is a little dirty and there are definitely nicer beaches in the area (Mirissa, Dikwalla). The reef break is a few minutes down the beach. The group lessons are held with a 3:1 or 4:1 student-instructor ratio (which is a good group size) and the guys (Fisher, Rafa, Sam) are enthusiastic, optimistic and helpful. They could spend more time on explaining the break(s), surf theory, etiquette, how to manage the board in the water etc. I’m not a beginner, but others were so some of that basic knowledge needs to be taught, even if that surfing experience is a one-off event for many. The line-up at at least the beach break is empty even during high season, so there’s a bit less danger, however that doesn’t mean anyone with a surfboard shouldn’t know a few basics (think drop-ins and flying boards…)
The by far biggest downside is the lack of boards and the quality of some of the boards. There are nowhere near enough boards to accommodate all surfing guests (plus some others, e.g. walk-ins or those of the partner hostel). Part of the package is “unlimited use of board” during the day, even outside of the lessons - yet there was often no equipment around to be used as lessons were still ongoing. Often even the lessons had to be spread out more than necessary as there weren’t enough boards to do them at the same time. To make it worse, some boards are clearly broken or dinged to a point of being risky to take it out to the water. The selection is also very limited - there are a few foamies, a few huge hardboards (8’2” and larger), and at best a handful of minimals/funboards. If you have your own board, then by all means: bring it. This particular aspect is really not acceptable - this is a surfcamp, not just a hostel that happens to have a few boards lying around. A surf camp needs to have enough boards to accommodate everyone if at full capacity at any time during the day, and it needs a selection that caters to a wide range of surfers with various levels of surfing skills. I’ve been to several camps before all over the world and while the quality of the boards is often mediocre, there was never a shortage.

Overall, this is not the worst choice, but I'm not sure if it's the best either. The cost for the camp is at Western European level, which is normal for surfcamps anywhere in the world - but for this one, you're not fully getting your money's worth. A little bit of effort, TLC and a few small changes could potentially make this a really great place, though.
title: Mixed feelings

text:
There is no doubt Sergeant House is absolutely beautiful, we had the 'sea view pavillion' and the room was spotless and took our breath away when we first walked in, we could believe our luck. The grounds outside are all immaculate and very peaceful. We were due to stay 4 nights however due to a few problems we checked out a night early which sadly put a dampener on our experience there. 

Firstly I really think the 'sea view pavillion' should not be advertised as a sea view. The room is beautiful and it has a large balcony with beautiful views, but we walked the whole way along it and could only see a tiny bit of sea through a load of palm trees if you squinted. There is definitely a view but do not expect a sea view.

Sadly on our third night there we discovered a cockroach issue in our room. The room was spotless in every other way so we were surprised by this, but we discovered 7 large cockroaches climbing up the mosquito net on our bed (inside and out) in the space of a couple of hours. We have travelled a lot in Asia and tropical countries and understand cockroaches come with the territory to a certain extend but for the price we were paying we weren't very happy about these visitors.

The water supply to our bathroom was very sporadic and would often go off for hours at a time so we were unable to shower, wash our hands or flush the toliet. Again for the price we were paying we didnt't feel that this was acceptable. 

There seemed to be a lot of staff around but only one of them spoke an adequate amount of English which was a little frustrating a times. (Apparently the owner was away, who I think is discussed quite a lot in the other reviews). We were under the impression that we would be able to have dinner here but when we went to investigate on our first night we were just told no. Sadly I was feeling very unwell so my partner had to leave me by myself in order to go and find somewhere for him to eat and they didn't seem to be able to help us out which was a shame.

The final point I have to make I have to stress I am aware that this wasn't the fault of Sergeant House but still feel I need to make people aware. On our third night (a wednesday night) the bar across the road 'Happy Beach' had a big party. The music was incredibly loud, so much so that the bass was making our room shake and no amount of ear plugs or head phones managed to even slightly drown the music out. This went on until gone 2am and we were wide awake until this point. As this was supposed to be the relaxing part of our trip and considering Sergeant House was by far the most expensive place we stayed we were very annoyed, especially as it had been advertised and being 'quiet and tranquil' away from the noisy bars of unawantuna beach. 

Sadly all these things and the total lack of sleep on our third night meant that we decided to leave a night early. After complaining about the water issue and the cockroaches they did give us a 10% discount on our stay which was good of them.

This property really is beautiful and the member of staff who did speak english was very helpful and we are grateful to him but there does seems to be a few teething problems which need sorting out.  

The noise on the last night we realise was not their fault but sadly it did kind of ruin it for us but maybe we were just unlucky.

We were excited to stay at this hotel due to the glowing reviews online, and even once we arrived at the property we were upgraded to a suite!

However, as our stay unfolded we were met with a deluge of bugs in our room.  Aware the weather was awful, we were staying essentially in a jungle, and bugs are to be expected - but this was an infestation.  Whilst the staff worked to clean them away, they kept appearing even after they removed a nest in the curtains!  Whilst it was treated  efficiently, it didn't feel like it was being solved and wouldn't be after we left.
We had, a few days prior, stayed on a remote island in a glamping tent surrounded by the wild and didnt experience anything like the issues here - so the jungle is only so much of a reason!  Rest of the hotel did seem unaffected however.

Due to this, we decided to leave a day early and move onto our next location.  So in total we had 2 nights here.

Whilst there staff were friendly, service was good.  We were suprised that the dinner menu is essentially one main course option, and if you don't like it then they can rustle up some pasta - that's it.  Seemed odd for a five star hotel.

They don't do lunch options btw!

Our suite is advertised as having a rainfall shower and a TV - it had neither.

Michel is a good host / hotel owner and despite trying to sort things out, its unfortunate we didn't feel comfortable in the hotel, struggled to sleep and decided to leave early to continue our luxury honeymoon.
title: Unfortunate experience

text: Hmmm..... this is a difficult one.  Start positive.  Excellent staff, friendly, helpful, attentive.  Excellent kitchen -- certainly above average and I am a picky foodie.  Good location.  Nice views from the balcony of thick forest tree tops and the foothills in the distance.  BUT after 16 days in Sri Lanka I cannot say that the Lake Lodge is competitive on value offered for money demanded compared to many other places we stayed.  Three nights, with meals taken breakfast and dinner there was close to $1000 for a couple.  Why is that not good value?  Now the negatives -- the hotel is poured concrete everywhere.  So the room reminded me of my freshman dormatory with its concrete work space and even poured concrete end tables next to the bed.  This stark and souless construction could have been softed with lots of local products, fabrics, masks, art work, to make it warmer and cozier rather than cold and sterile.  The wifi/internet was the WORST of the trip.  During the day it is agonizingly slow to read a newspaper or do email and at night it gets essentially non-functional.  Forget about streaming video content.  The TV had few stations (no CNN or BBC) and those channels it had were very poor, snowy images out of the 1950s.  The room was also not properly cleaned and serviced - the Please Be Green card on the bed said linens changed every other day but that didn't happen (I could tell because the linens had small holes in my corner of the bed and they never disappeared).  The bathroom on arrival had, at eye level when sitting on the toilet, two large spider webs with large and very much alive spiders that I had to sweep down to avoid company in the loo.  And the upper shelf in the bathroom, where water glasses were left turn rim down, was thick, very thick, with dust.  It clearly had not been dusted in a long time, and yet our water glasses were sitting in the fluff.  All this is to say that, for three nights and $1000 you can do much better.  This is a hotel whose reach exceeds its grasp, which is a pity because the local staff are all wonderful people.  I would not go back, sad to say.
title: Not value for money

The conclusion is that I feel it has potential but just hasn’t fully realised it yet.

text:
We stayed at the Thaala Bentota for 6 nights on an all inclusive basis at the end of a long but excellent tour. It’s a very modern hotel but small, with one bar and one restaurant. Staff were friendly, if slow serving, and the food was excellent. The public beach is beautiful but the hotel was nowhere near the standard of hotel we stayed in around the island. Although I don’t like writing negative reviews, there are significant hotel flaws which I wish we had had known about before booking. There are a number of reasons why we wouldn’t stay at the hotel again, mainly stemming from poor management:

1. the hotel makes it clear that it is close to a railway line and there might be some “occasional noise”. It does not make it clear that it’s very close to the station and that you are woken by the 6.00am Mail train each morning - if you manage to sleep through that there is little chance with the 6.30am train. The trains are far more numerous and noisier than expected and a major disturbance
2. the hotel is by a beautiful beach but the hotel is at pains to say that it’s a public beach and nothing to do with them. Signs and instructions on arrival make it plain that you are not allowed to take hotel towels to the beach and there are no hotel sun beds on the beach either which we were looking forward to. The hotel grounds are lovely but there’s a desperate need for new sun beds and parasols - there are currently far too few and the existing beds and mattresses need replacing as they’re in very poor condition 
3. the poorly thought through  business model of catering for B&B, Breakfast and half board at lunch or evening and all inclusive. As the hotel refuses to ask guests to wear coloured wrist bands you are constantly asked for your room number and have to sign for all drinks from the bar, including water and coffee. This is an incredibly slow and antiquated paper based system which makes service even more pedestrian 
4. as a result of their business model numbers for lunch are often too small to open the buffet at the Breeze restaurant, so you are forced to eat instead from the very limited a la carte or snack menu in the chatters bar. We ate there three days out of 5. Due to the chaotic organisation lunch took over an hour when you just wanted to be outside and tables were very slow to be cleared
5. the all inclusive offer is limited, ending at 10.00pm, and there is no all day snack bar. Bizarrely whilst red and white wine were readily available, they refused to sell Rosé wine by the glass - instead asking you to buy a bottle for 14,200 rupees or £38! We queried the price three times and were given the same price each time. 
6. Despite the pride over the architectural design there are clear flaws. The open reception area is lovely but the corridors on the upper level are dark and unfriendly with 2 deeply unattractive concrete stairways to the pool area. In addition guests with rooms to the south end have to walk through the Chatters bar after visiting the beach or pool, and Speedo trunks are neither attractive or healthy when you are eating 
7. Our Deluxe room was very large and airy with a nice balcony but it was cleaned in 6 minutes. The shower cubicle wasn’t cleaned properly during our whole stay

We raised our points with management several times but there was no response, and managers only became visible around the hotel after our second complaint. They had no answer for the scam with the Rosé wine. We had a very nice five day stay but the hotel should be so much better and aim for better quality and customer experience. It’s not a bad hotel but it was nowhere near the standard of the other excellent hotels we stayed at.
title: Nice Hotel but what I would have liked to know before booking

text:
When we arrived at the hotel we were greeted promptly and checked in right away. We were shown to our room and our luggage was carried to our room by 2 porters. ( they do expect a tip of course !) The room was clean and the bathroom was large and had a collection of toiletries, ( shampoo, conditioner & shower gel) - a decent hairdryer was also provided. Our room was cleaned regularly and sheets and towels were changed on a daily basis. We did find the guys who cleaned the room to be a little over friendly- randomly knocking on our door - almost every day-
to see if we’d liked the towel display on our bed - which could’ve been a swan/ 2 swans/ elephant- you get the gist ! Sometimes even stepping into our room - which I felt was a little intrusive. This was obviously in the hope of receiving a tip - which we did give on a regular basis- but then found they started loitering around our room - it was almost as if they knew what time of day we were going back to our room! A point to mention also is that there is a train line running parallel to the front of the hotel which you could hear anytime from around 4.30 in the morning - it almost felt like the train would be ploughing its way right through your room on occasions.
There are 2 large swimming pools and a couple of small pools for children. There are plenty of Sun loungers and towels which you get from a little hut next to the main pool. The towels could do with being renewed -some looked a bit grubby, however, they always smelled freshly laundered-mattresses for Sun loungers could do with  being upgraded- looked a little grubby , but they served their purpose. The pool area was kept tidy although could do with a good old power wash in places. 
Now onto food- we were staying half board - so it was breakfast and  dinner. Breakfast was your normal selection of fruit , jams , bacon - various egg dishes, salads , bread , curry etc. 2 people cooking omelettes and bacon & tea, coffee and fruit juices. Dinner was a variety of beef,pork,seafood, rices, salads & puddings. Nothing spectacular- but we did not go hungry. My one criticism was that the food was not very hot. Service was okay - a case of the highest tippers received the better service ! We did eat in the snack bar a couple of times & the food was good and nicely presented. All food/ drinks purchased have a service charge added of 10% & v.a.t on top of the price on the menus. My husband and I ordered a couple of burgers one day which was around 4400 Sri Lankan Rupees & then an additional 1200 was added onto the bill. Just bear this in mind if/when tipping! There is also a lack of entertainment- I would not like to think we had been there for a fortnight with teenagers- there was a pool table and a few games/ books but that was it. It was a case of back to your room after dinner as there was nothing going on.
The beach was okay but not the brilliant white sands of the Caribbean. We walked the length and breadth of the whole beach outside of the hotel and found some parts to be littered with plastic bottles etc. We even found a hyperdermic needle one day- this could’ve been washed up I suppose. The sea was very choppy and red flags were up for the full 6 days we were there. We did go in for a dip to say we’d been in the Indian Ocean, but you could not swim in it as there were undercurrents.
You can walk into Bentota town which take’s around 10 minutes across the bridge & we did spot couple of crocodiles!! Bentota is not the cleanest as in most cases in Sri Lanka but we only went for a few snacks &a bottle of gin from the liquor store which cost around £12.50. Shops selling dried fish and fresh fish, chillis and other spices. It was an experience. We did not feel threatened or uncomfortable walking into town as long as you are prepared for a bit of hassle from tuk tuk/taxi drivers and shop vendors- but everyone has to make a living & as long as you are firm and polite they tend to let you walk on by & get the message eventually.
On our last day we checked out and then about an hour before we were to leave we were hunted down by one of the ladies in reception and asked to leave a review on trip advisor- she was very adamant we did it there & then and hovered over us until we’d completed one and submitted it. We felt very pressurised into doing this and at the time felt we could not be completely honest and the who scenario was pretty uncomfortable. They are obviously under a lot of pressure from management to make sure good reviews are posted and negative reviews are not welcomed. We had a pleasant stay but this was not as pleasurable as our stay at the Melheim resort in the hills where we could have stayed for longer and the service there was exemplary.
title: A pleasant stay

The food was ‘okay’. It felt like it catered much more for Indian and Sri Lankan guests which is fine, but for the cost of making a curry in Sri Lanka with largely locally sourced ingredients the mark up was huge!

I felt it was significantly overpriced compared to similar priced hotels in Sri Lanka.

Additional activities are offered by the hotel but they are all at quite significant prices. I wouldn’t mind paying those prices if I thought the money was being passed on to the staff involved but I suspect the large mark ups go to the hotel itself and given that they don’t seem to be using these huge mark ups to invest in necessary ongoing maintenance and refreshing the decor it seems frankly just greedy?

The spa and gym look stuck in the 1980s.

Personally I would recommend looking at other hotels in this area like Jetwing.

So me and my wife visited The heritance tea factory for our Anniversary. We were on a tour to SriLanka for 7 nights out of which we had planned 2 nights here. After atleast a 15 mins discussion that when I already have LKR then why should I pay in $ or by card? No one agreed to my requests. Then when I did pay them in $ (cash), the change given back to me was in LKR. The surprising point is that their exchange rate was much lesser than the one we would have gotten from bank/airport. (Atleast 15 LKR less). On asking the change back in $ they started showing me their company policy. I mean when I am ready to pay in your own currency you dont want that then you want to return the change back to me in your currency. What a Joke. Extremely shameful.

One more incident took place on the 2nd day when I asked for a water bottle for my room and I was refused saying that it will be chargeable infact all the water bottles which were given to me on daily basis will be charged to my account. I think they were expecting me to go to the restaurant and ask them for a glass of water everytime I felt thirsty.

All their practices were to make more and more money. I regretted my decision of booking a stay here. Their are many other beautiful properties in Nuwara Eliya.

text:
ITC Ratnadpia has a lot going for it, but my stay was a mix of great moments and oversights.

The Good
The Sky Bridge Lounge is a standout. I loved the no-children policy and the enforced dress code. It's rare to find a lounge that keeps things sophisticated. The weekend live band was a nice surprise and pretty good, though they could lean into more upbeat music. The lounge’s setup is too fantastic to stick with slow songs all night. On our last night, when they picked up the pace, the vibe transformed. People were chair dancing, singing, and mingling. It felt alive, the way it should. A special shoutout to Hasitha, whose local tips and friendly service made our trip to Sri Lanka much smoother.

The design of the hotel is beautiful. From the impressive lobby to the unique common spaces, it’s clear a lot of thought went into the aesthetics. Rooms with lake or sea views are a treat if you’re lucky enough to get one. The breakfast buffet was solid, with plenty of options, and the on-site Chinese restaurant exceeded expectations. Good food, fair pricing, and a large menu (though it really needs page numbers). The staff we did engage with were friendly and genuinely kind.

The Not-So-Good (the growing pains)
Cleanliness was not up to par. Crumbs on seats and couches in both lounges and uncleared tables at the breakfast buffet. It just didn’t feel like a luxury hotel. Sky bridge lounge buffet needs supervision as one incident was especially off-putting. I saw a guest after dining half their plate at their table put some food back onto the common serving platter. I was done after that.

Service was inconsistent, particularly in the lobby lounge. I stayed there for hours without being approached, even as other guests were attended to almost immediately. It felt like attention depended on who you were.

The Ugly
The rooms were the most disappointing part of the stay. At first, everything looks sleek. modern, and new... until your eyes adjust. For a hotel that opened in April, the level of wear and tear was shocking. Both rooms we stayed in had significant mildew and grime in the showers, water seeping through tiles outside the shower, rust-stained balconies, and poorly finished surfaces (scratched marble, paint on wood, etc). This place is going to have significant water issues. The mattress was rock-hard. If you’re a side sleeper, prepare for a sore shoulder. These aren’t the details you’d expect from an ITC property, and they really undermine the otherwise luxurious feel of the hotel.

Overall
ITC Ratnadpia has the potential to be a fantastic destination. The design is stunning, the lounge is a real highlight, and the pricing feels fair for what’s on offer, but this place feels like it was rushed to open and missing the precision associated with the ITC brand.
title: A Mixed Experience at ITC Ratnadpia
